d4432ee30b6780e22825e6cc0619c2ae.text: It appears the word ''gluten'' is being used in two different ways.

a977b7e232c1623d0fb2ef619f156fa5.text: The applicable definition given in the [[Oxford English Dictionary]] is:

cf6b5630a4b467c72dded604e7256473.text: :''3. The nitrogenous part of the flour of wheat or other grain, which remains behind as a viscid substance when the starch is removed by kneading the flour in a current of water.''

b35f87c26849de4363a22e13505202ee.text: Further to this, the [[American Heritage Dictionary]] (which is known for using [[corpus linguistics]] and combining [[Prescription_and_description|prescriptive and descriptive]] elements) gives the following definition:

22e4925031bdfc88900c1415a00d4de5.text: :''A mixture of plant proteins occurring in cereal grains, chiefly corn and wheat, used as an adhesive and as a flour substitute.''

42807606e5a7d459b27e53450f722584.text: This article defines gluten as "composed of the proteins [[gliadin]] and [[glutenin]]".  This is a definition which appears from my research to be a common one among food scientists and celiac patients, but it is not the usual dictionary definition.   I can find many cases of the broader definition in present use; for example, there are agricultural by-products called "corn gluten meal" and "rice gluten meal" which are used as animal feed.  Also, the OED notes a historical precedent:

03dc5749a4ded584f361e56d3ab71a69.text: :''1876 HARLEY Mat. Med. (ed. 6) 371 Oats contain a larger proportion of gluten than any of the other cereals in use.''

ff956e26b049d499e24e4c8a1bb8084d.text: *Don't forget corn gluten as herbicide! There is clearly a distinction between the modern scientific meaning of "gluten" as spelled out in the article and what's been loosely called gluten in the past ("the stuff that makes dough sticky" back to the 18th century) and the recent present ("corn gluten"). This article very much should mention the different use of the terms, as the confusion leads to incorrect conclusions (for example, is corn gluten bad for celiac patients? No, not at all -- people avoiding gluten can eat all the corn tortillas they want, like I did yesterday for lunch.) But thanks for raising this question; I'm fairly new at the gluten-avoidance game, and myself was puzzled by the other uses of "gluten". --[[User:Jpgordon|jpgordon]][[User talk:Jpgordon|∇∆∇∆]] 17:27, 5 October 2005 (UTC)

eee7ad178383ebf651c1c2f5115ad73c.text: Note: the medical definiton of gluten is only as precise as the immunochemistry. If tomorrow a new food grass appeared in Bromeae or Aveneae that had similarly toxic glutens the medical definition would be extended to cover those new CD causing glutens. Alternatively if it was shown the barley (pure) was free of toxic glutens it would be removed (over a decade of ranchorous discussion). What defines purity- serological approaches and thorough feild inspections. What defines reactivity- other than ambiguous biopsy results, T-cell assays and immunochemistry.

b8e6b66c4797b52465f62c5b1445bdfd.text: Note:Allergies to wheat albumins and globulins are also considered gluten allergies even though these allergies extend, often, over broad taxa. The medical definition of gluten is for clinical application of treatment, the Gluten-Free diet. A gluten-free diet that is strictly gluten-free (by the strinct definition) can contain rye and barley, therefore the strict is not being used.

199b305b73d55aa7fd28e86bbc0e6daf.text: Glutens are defined by genetic relationships (Homologs) within plant phyla, which extends over the common seed producing plants, but especially cereal grasses. These definitions are in wide use in the literature. These definitions are largely based on the components of glutens within seeds of plants, most of which evolved from common ancestral seeds. For example the gamma gliadins in wheat are ancestral to omega and alpha gliadins. Though by definition none would be recognized as glutens, strictly, or gliadins in that ancestral species. In fact the prolamins contributed by aegilops tauschii strangulatum as a result of introgression into wheat (8000 years ago) are not recognized as terminologically as gliadins. but as A. tauschii prolamins and glutelins, none the less they are identical to that wheat subset.

fa8b13dd7a4d24a788be9477c75ff882.text: When one uses the word [grain] gluten it is implicit that these are discussing the seed storage proteins (comparable to [wheat] gluten) of that plant.

9e21117bbe18dbb65cc554c1b1022704.text: Meaning of the Term "Gluten". ''There is no single definition of the term "gluten".''

10176f2a155b447fd7a8827b0c941215.text: ''The term "gluten" refers to a specific complex of proteins that forms when '''wheat flour''' is mixed with a liquid and physically manipulated, such as in the kneading of a bread.''

bf5f483776a23e02b95deb77a44abdac.text: of the low level or protein. So that the technical definition is of little use unless you are discussing bread making.

45e9db681a4621a800aeb972712a2444.text: and globulins as cofactors. Gluten amylase is responsible for converting starch to sugar that allows a better rise, although amylase is now supplimented.

327077f543ea3c89a5e84c7990bf238a.text: ''Although, strictly speaking, "gluten" pertains '''only to wheat proteins''', this term is frequently used to refer to the combination of prolamin and glutelin proteins naturally occurring in other grains, including those that have not been demonstrated to cause harmful effects in individuals with celiac disease (e.g., "corn gluten" and "rice gluten)''

7f0a8a6485aa6c02afb61ef2411840b6.text: ''Finding 8.The safety assessment-based approach is a viable approach to establish a threshold for gluten using currently available LOAEL data for celiac disease. An overall uncertainty factor should be estimated from the data and applied to the LOAEL to establish a threshold for gluten. Any threshold derived from this approach should be reevaluated as new research data become available. Available data are insufficient at the current time to use this approach to establish a threshold for '''oat gluten''' for those individuals with celiac disease who are also sensitive to oats. However, it is likely that a threshold based on wheat gluten would be protective for individuals susceptible to oat gluten.''

7e183c4c6720144e21a2b0060e82b01d.text: Finally, gluten is not "toxic" per se, intolerance to it is the result of an autoimmune response, not any direct effect of the gluten protiens on the gut. [[User:Kantokano|Kantokano]] 15:00, 10 September 2007 (UTC)

6a7cc63dc1ff2f2b126100d697bbcc7d.text: :The sentence "Allergies to wheat albumins and globulins are also considered gluten allergies..." doesn't jibe.  Per the [[Triticeae glutens]] article, [[albumin]] is one of the four seed storage proteins in wheat, rye, and barley; but that article indicates that the promalin and glutelin proteins are the components involved in gluten sensitivity.  But per the Mayo Clinic article on the [http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/wheat-allergy/DS01002/DSECTION=causes causes of wheat allergy], all four can cause wheat allergies (with a distinction made between a food allergy and a food sensitivity).  Per the [http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/food-allergy/AN01109 Mayo Clinic article on food allergy], a food intolerance (e.g. celiac disease) is a food sensitivity but not a food allergy - though an individual may be both sensitive and allergic to a food.  For example, a person may have celiac disease and also be allergic to wheat.  I believe that this clarification would clear up the statements regarding a gluten-free diet (which contradict the [[gluten-free diet]] article and [http://www.fda.gov/ForConsumers/ConsumerUpdates/ucm265212.htm US FDA GF labeling guidelines].  A wheat-free diet is designed for people with wheat allergies; a gluten-free diet is designed for people with gluten sensitivity.[[User:Pegordon|Penelope Gordon]] ([[User talk:Pegordon|talk]]) 09:23, 14 March 2013 (UTC)

8661537e9b332503d66299df1df79e32.text: This whole article seems heavily biased in that it makes it makes it sound like gluten is primarily some sort of additive or food byproduct, rather than a basic component of certain grains (correct me if I'm wrong on the facts here). So, except for the part on "added gluten" this should be called something like "function of gluten in bread-making", not "use of gluten in bread products".

746c5d4e6f7f0e3b68bffbeca2a8a0f2.text: Hard and soft are descriptions of wheat texture, not dough strength. Hard textured wheats can have strong or weak gluten on a continuous scale. Even in the soft wheats with strong gluten, the gluten tends to be weaker than most hard textured wheats.(I'm a soft wheat breeder)-- [[User:Edgeben|Edgeben]] ([[User talk:Edgeben|talk]]) 23:59, 16 January 2015 (UTC)[[User:edgeben]]

Presumably fact-checkers at PBS did their homework before engaging him for a 90-minute special and if someone with access to the literature can cite support for Perlmutter's contentions, this thesis should be added to the article. Perlmutter also cites sugar and carbs as similar promoters of inflammation.  [[User:Frankatca|Frankatca]] ([[User talk:Frankatca|talk]]) 01:57, 13 March 2015 (UTC)

6ad9931b6983e0da2f0b14e39de9baa6.text: I agree to use these references to improve the information, but we must adjust. This reference states:<ref name="shewry" />

af4298b801d52fc59735c5413a58f350.text: Gluten has low content in the essential amino acid lysine and therefore, it has a low biological value (see [[Biological value#Properties of the protein source]]), as stated in the ref <ref name=LamacchiaCamarca2014>{{cite journal | vauthors = Lamacchia C, Camarca A, Picascia S, Di Luccia A, Gianfrani C| title = Cereal-based gluten-free food: how to reconcile nutritional and technological properties of wheat proteins with safety for celiac disease patients | journal = Nutrients | volume = 6| issue = 2| pages = 575–90| date = Jan 29, 2014| pmid = 24481131|pmc= 3942718| doi = 10.3390/nu6020575 |type= Review}}</ref> (''"From a nutritional point of view, gluten exclusion does not entail particular problems, being a mixture of proteins with low nutritional and biological value"'') and lower than the rest of proteins in wheat. We can not say that it is the most important source of protein in wheat from a nutritional point of view, but the most abundant.

a2d533bc2eaf965f162051dc12d2ff12.text: [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4998136/ "The data in Table 4 support the widely accepted view that the first limiting amino acid in wheat grain is lysine with other essential amino acids being present in adequate amounts, at least for adults.  The lower contents of essential amino acids in white flour compared with wholegrain relate to the high content of lysine‐poor prolamin storage proteins (gluten proteins) in the starchy endosperm. These proteins are restricted to the starchy endosperm cells, where they account for about 80% of the total proteins, and have unusual amino acid compositions with high contents of glutamine and proline and low contents of lysine (reviewed by Shewry and Halford 2002; Shewry 2007; Shewry et al. 2009a). This contrasts with the proteins present in the other grain tissues which are more lysine‐rich."]

41e6dcee85a45b404eaa3151960e16b5.text: :Problems with the above analysis are as follows: 1) the quote from Shewry (2015) does not eliminate gluten's overall contribution of 11 amino acids to the diet, but rather is saying that the lysine content is less than optimal. [http://jxb.oxfordjournals.org/content/60/6/1537/T1.expansion.html This table from Shewry (2009),] giving quantitative values for amino acids in wheat proteins (most of which is from gluten), shows whole wheat as an excellent source of amino acids compared to the FAO/WHO standards, i.e., evidence for wheat protein including gluten as a nutritious food source. Gluten is supplying most of those amino acid contents; 2) "low biological value" is only in comparison to other ''high''-protein food sources shown in the table. Among ''all'' food sources, wheat has relatively high protein/amino acid value; 3) the Lamacchia reference cites no specific physiological evidence for "low biological value", an outdated, poorly defined and controversial measurement as presented [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_value#Criticism here.] There are no credible reviews supporting use of this term; 4) the current discussion on gluten as a significant source of amino acids for healthy human nutrition presented at the [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wheat#Health_effects Wheat article] should be duplicated here for balance. Summarizing, gluten is a) a valid, significant amino acid source from wheat as food for billions of people; and b) it causes serious adverse effects in a small percentage of the general population. The current article is heavily biased toward part b. --[[User:Zefr|Zefr]] ([[User talk:Zefr|talk]]) 21:41, 11 December 2016 (UTC)

f11dec55e1621a3ca0115c330d9dc66b.text: ::If you read the ref, the paragraph above of which I quoted, you will see this:

83b313923e11e6d4c5b4066974f1cc94.text: ::[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4998136/ The contribution of wheat to human diet and health]

4ab75e52e7fe7d917efa011ec282e243.text: ::'''''Protein nutritional quality is determined by the proportions of essential amino acids''', as these cannot be synthesized by animals and hence must be provided in the diet. '''<u>If only one essential amino acid is limiting, the others will be broken down and excreted resulting in restricted growth in humans and loss of nitrogen present in the diet. Ten amino acids are strictly essential: lysine''',</u> isoleucine, leucine, phenylalanine, tyrosine, threonine, tryptophan, valine, histidine, and methionine. However, cysteine is often also included as it can only be synthesized from methionine, with combined proportions of cysteine and methionine often being presented. '''The requirements for essential amino acids are lower for adults where amino acids are required only for maintenance, than for children where they are also required for growth.'''''

39bd5fc09f8ef0de02846c39f55f3342.text: :: ''"Lamacchia reference cites no specific physiological evidence for "low biological value""'' It is clear that the reviewers of Lamacchia's article are specialist and therefore aware of this fact, whereby, despite not including references, gave the article's approval. But we have the Shewry reference of 2015 to use instead, with a broader explanation.

3947f08d6052219dd826a45cda4fc6d5.text: ::This is a more recent review of 2015 from the same author (Shewry) than the other older ref you are mentioning, (Shewry 2009). And the continuous selection of wheat is increasing the gluten content,  because of its unique viscoelastic properties, enabling the preparation of diverse nutritious foods such as breads, noodles, and pasta, which is what manufacturers demand. Anyway, in the table from Shewry (2009) we can see that both grain and flour are deficient in the strictly essential amino acid lysine:

f87cb9f9d2b07fd341cdc539b9f87782.text: ::To achieve the neutrality and balance you are asking for, we must include a summary of these paragraphs. The higher the amount of gluten, which is deficient in lysine, the lower nutritional value of wheat. ''"If only one essential amino acid is limiting, the others will be broken down and excreted resulting in restricted growth in humans and loss of nitrogen present in the diet"'' And ''"other essential amino acids being present in adequate amounts, at least for adults"'' means that is not clear in children.

5233235fe54d5d7ef95de287dcdf3221.text: ::'''[http://jxb.oxfordjournals.org/content/60/6/1537/T1.expansion.html] Recommended levels of essential amino acid lysine for adult humans FAO/WHO/UNU''' (expressed as mg g−1 protein): '''45'''; wheat grain: '''28''' flour: '''22'''

5b37b67222e5c77ea2ae2f397d2f1192.text: :::From the more rigorous Shewry references, we can acknowledge the "lysine limiting" effect qualitatively, but there are no quantitative data to confirm a deficiency effect on human nutrition and there is likely over-interpretation of the limiting effect because protein consumption via gluten does not occur in isolation, i.e., except in famine, the typical diet has varied protein sources allowing correction of gluten's lysine limiting effect. It would be misleading to state in the article that gluten in isolation has a negative impact on protein intake and overall nutrition. [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protein_Digestibility_Corrected_Amino_Acid_Score#Limitations More here] (although a poorly referenced article, likely because dietary metabolites like amino acid nitrogen are difficult to study in vivo), [http://jn.nutrition.org/content/130/7/1865S.long here,] and [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23107528 here]. --[[User:Zefr|Zefr]] ([[User talk:Zefr|talk]]) 00:07, 12 December 2016 (UTC)

73912798e3a84443544fa5f6f157e430.text: Just an FYI: The paragraph above this one is 100% incorrect on its face. Angiosperms definitely have seeds. 6ddbec497e11609fb7c24cedf9f29c8d.text: :::I disagree. "The occurrence of oat avenin toxicity depends on the oat cultivar consumed" is a passive construction that doesn't make sense. I can't parse the phrase "toxicity occurs." Are you trying to say, there is gluten in oats which can have bad effects on people who are disposed to have bad reactions to it"? Perhaps you have a level of expertise that makes this construction transparent to you, but I think for most readers it implies that oats are toxic. And why are you linking "oat avenin toxicity" to "oats" again? Are you intending to say that oats are toxic? Toxic, for the lay person, means poisonous to most people at most doses. It is my understanding that gluten causes an immune reaction in some people, and it is that reaction which has bad effects. And why is this in the lede? Do you think that the most salient thing about gluten is that it affects 1-6% of people in this way? This seems like undue weight. By that logic, I could go put "tree pollen toxicity occurs, causing seasonal allergy toxicity, sneezing, red eyes and itchy skin" in the lede of "pollen" when in fact it belongs in "allergy" with a link to "pollen" and should be re-written in accessible English.[[User:DolyaIskrina|DolyaIskrina]] ([[User talk:DolyaIskrina|talk]]) 06:37, 21 April 2019 (UTC)

be431be7d0b00a846199dde7e6b34a93.text: I'm drawing out a discussion I've had on this page because I think we need consensus on this question. On this page gluten is said to be [[cytotoxic]] which to the average lay reader means that gluten is in and of itself poisonous to most people at most doses. The cytotoxicity page refers to spider and snake venom as well the the chemicals used in chemo-therapy.

af376745d8c917a4e9dac313f1ac3be1.text: '''But the source do indeed say "gluten toxicity"'''

635bf24d3cec14fafef803cad332aa10.text: It's true that the sources refer to "gluten toxicity" but my reading of those sources seems to show that they are using that phrase as a shorthand. In a similar way a physicist might say "water always chooses the shortest route" or "electrons want to move to the lowest orbital". Even though the physicists literally said "water chooses" "and electrons want" you would be guilty of WP:SYNTH if you said "physics proves water and electrons want and think."

12f06dd1e4dcc731bdadf5f59c6994a1.text: '''But gluten has real toxic effects of patients with celiacs and NCGRD'''

806d14f1f765bb9c93a65f792c20bc15.text: Yes, but those patients are less than 10% of the population. Spider venom is toxic to 99% of the people who are exposed to it. Whatever the technical definition of toxic is, I don't think gluten qualifies in the same way as spider venom.

19cc9ff83e0c06564ddf7504046782ce.text: My proposal. Every reference to the bad effects of gluten should be phrased to reflect the idea that gluten '''triggers''' responses (immune and autoimmune) '''in some people''' which have toxic '''effects'''.[[User:DolyaIskrina|DolyaIskrina]] ([[User talk:DolyaIskrina|talk]]) 22:52, 7 May 2019 (UTC)

6012c626d0f9145b0b20695704ed5836.text: :That a Wikipedia page is not complete and does not include all the information / examples, does not remove toxicity from a substance.

ce86c7be1cd9b920718e4408c48b3806.text: :Your proposal ''"Every reference to the bad effects of gluten should be phrased to reflect the idea that gluten '''triggers''' responses (immune and autoimmune) '''in some people''' which have toxic '''effects'''"'' is inaccurate.

2cab57c61cf0776755030cefd6b58869.text: :'''Gliadin causes cell damage directly''', reducing cell viability (from 20% to 60%), leading to morphological alterations characterized by apoptotic findings and cytoskeletal injuries, and also activates zonulin signaling '''irrespective of the genetic expression of autoimmunity''', leading to increased intestinal permeability to macromolecules. PMID 16273608 PMID 16635908 PMID 14615062

b5810f31401fd19ce2af5712f8f09473.text: :PMID 26217073 [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4507091/ See: “Besides the possible alteration of the immune system, '''gluten presents some peculiar biologic properties that induce intestinal damage'''(15). Different in vitro studies ...”] <small>15. Elli L, Dolfini E, Bardella MT. Gliadin cytotoxicity and in vitro cell cultures. Toxicol Lett. 2003;146:1–8.</small>

fc0d4ee09f329f9ff002480a4a8b595b.text: :The toxicity of gluten has been known and studied for almost half a century. There are dozens of studies.

d3af8159b0b32893643aacc9f7d487df.text: :PMID 16273608 [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4436719/ Since Hudson ''et a''l first observed the '''inhibited growth and morphological modifications''' in different human cell lines induced by gliadin exposure, a number of in vitro studies have confirmed the '''cytotoxicity of the peptide'''.]

c1473eaec0151efae7416b247d875bc5.text: :PMID 28810029 "Previous studies have shown that '''gliadin can cause an immediate and transient increase in gut permeability'''. This permeating effect is secondary to the binding of specific undigestible gliadin fragments to the CXCR3 chemokine receptor with subsequent release of zonulin, a modulator of intercellular tight junctions. This process takes place '''in all individuals who ingest gluten'''."

ce9ae3de39970b276e2c3b1baec020a1.text: :PMID 26217073 "The pathogenesis of NCGS is largely unknown, but a mixture of factors such as the stimulation of the innate immune system, '''the direct cytotoxic effects of gluten''', and probably the synergy with other wheat molecules, are clues for the complicated puzzle." --[[User:BallenaBlanca|BallenaBlanca]] 🐳 ♂ [[User talk:BallenaBlanca|<small>(Talk)</small>]] 19:51, 12 May 2019 (UTC)

b1c35ce39e67c3401616dcce825d48f0.text: :The variation in the percentage of people immune to a toxic substance, or that this percentage is "<s>small</s>big", does not make the substance non-toxic.

5247d295b86bb4c98d53b3684f415764.text: :::I'm hoping someone else can weigh in on this too. In vitro studies are not always conclusive about what happens en vivo. Gliadin is cytotoxic, but it is just a component of gluten. Does saying "gliadin is toxic" equal saying "gluten is toxic"? Further, the literature does not read the way you would expect it to if the toxicity of gliadin were the answer to the question of "what causes Celiacs and related disorders?" Why all the talk of "the puzzle"? In this abstract toxic is put in scare quotes. And the whole issue of toxicity is framed in the brackets of [for those who it is a problem]:

c6b808b8209a3eb5416b6bb480060238.text: ::::"Although a number of studies have been published concerning the role of T cells in inducing intestinal damage, little is known about the early stages in which gliadin (the toxic component of gluten) starts the whole process. In vitro two- and three-dimensional (multicellular spheroid) cell cultures are a simple and useful means of studying the direct cellular effects of gliadin and other '''"toxic"''' cereal peptides. Furthermore, in addition to improving our understanding of pathogenetic mechanisms, cell cultures can also be used to test modified peptides that could replace the toxic components present in the foods that '''celiac patients must avoid.'''[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/14615062]""

020df8d220754a7d8af69c895a3fd311.text: :::If the relevant epistemic community doesn't think the answer is "gluten is toxic, so you shouldn't eat it" then our page shouldn't read that way either. The toxicity of gliadin might be a piece of the puzzle, but it's not the only issue. Which would explain why it's only a problem for a small percentage of people. [[User:DolyaIskrina|DolyaIskrina]] ([[User talk:DolyaIskrina|talk]]) 21:51, 24 May 2019 (UTC)

0e8568491e2b6c910912be4ca8285762.text: {{quote|In home or restaurant cooking, gluten is prepared from [[flour]] by kneading the flour under water, agglomerating the gluten into an elastic network known as a [[dough]], and then washing out the [[starch]]. Starch granules [[suspension (chemistry)|disperse]] in low-temperature water, and the dispersed starch is [[sedimentation|sedimented]] and dried. If a [[salt|saline]] solution is used instead of water, a purer protein is obtained, with certain harmless [[impurity|impurities]] departing the solution with the starch. Where starch is the prime product, cold water is the favored solvent because the impurities depart from the gluten.}}

8d46e5991e984af44da61e5e9a0ccb11.text: ::::The article is slanted to a toxicity emphasis because it has been extensively edited and protected by an anti-gluten advocate. Other than acknowledging that gluten makes a small percentage of the population sick, all the evidence for toxicity derives from in vitro work - which leads to speculation about mechanisms in the clinical diagnosis - the description of which is unencyclopedic, [[WP:SYNTH]]. I removed in vitro content and sources from the lede, and moved the avenin discussion to the Celiac disease section. --[[User:Zefr|Zefr]] ([[User talk:Zefr|talk]]) 22:35, 24 May 2019 (UTC)

c892d66f5a4034f88336bcc00960d021.text: :{{Ping|DolyaIskrina}}, it seems like [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Gluten&diff=898631298&oldid=897234593 this] edit from {{Ping|Zefr}} alleviates or addresses the concern? As far as "on this page gluten is said to be cytotoxic which to the average lay reader means that gluten is in and of itself poisonous", as long as the article is clear - for example now it says "in vitro studies on cell cultures showed that gluten is cytotoxic" - then I don't think people will generalize this to "it is poisonous". However, that statement is not cited - and I wish it was, with a specific page number (I like to use the [[Template:Rp]] for these). Ideally, it would be helpful to mention what [[cytotoxicity]] means in context - are other common food components cytotoxic? And there are numbers used to express a level of cytotoxicity such as notably [[IC50]] (see [https://www.researchgate.net/post/What_is_the_best_term_IC50_CD50_ED50etc_to_express_cytotoxicity What is the best term (IC50, CD50, ED50...etc) to express cytotoxicity?]. Do we know the mechanism of cytotoxicity? It appears that the latest strand of "basic science" in this line of research would be something like [https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1590865818308077 Gliadin effect on the oxidative balance and DNA damage: An in-vitro, ex-vivo study] (2019). A decent summary of in vitro research appears at [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3605231/ Latest In vitro and in vivo models of celiac disease] (2013). It seems to point to a [[humanized mouse]] with [[interleukin-15]] overexpression as the latest. [[User:ImperfectlyInformed|II]] | ([[User_talk:ImperfectlyInformed|t]] - [[Special:Contributions/ImperfectlyInformed|c]]) 05:05, 26 May 2019 (UTC)

bbe79ff826c2ca68478eee20363dc00e.text: ::[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Gluten&diff=898873759&oldid=898631298 Further on the issue of supposed 'cytotoxicity',] after another look at the literature and [[WP:BRD]], I removed content and a source PMID 26217073 based mainly on primary research and self-admitted conjecture about the cellular pathology in NCGS. As {{u|ImperfectlyInformed}} states, the non-science lay reader would interpret discussion of 'cytotoxicity' as 'poison in gluten foods'. A skeptical science reader would question the leap of interpretation from feeling sick due to gluten sensitivity to having cells poisoned, which of course is impossible to adequately demonstrate with clinical research rigor. Even among scientists, on one side are anti-gluten advocates who loosely use the term 'cytotoxic' when evidence is only from in vitro studies (disqualified from general interpretation; see [[WP:MEDREV]]), while others, myself among them, feel the article should remain neutral without alarmist exaggeration discussing gluten 'cytotoxicity'. --[[User:Zefr|Zefr]] ([[User talk:Zefr|talk]]) 13:47, 26 May 2019 (UTC)

f492c73675a708a910f258280be4334a.text: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gluten#Increased_intestinal_permeability I'm removing the section and image] as these are theories and conjecture from lab research that mislead the non-science reader to believe there is impending pathology upon consuming gluten, possibly for everyone and certainly - as stated now - for those with gluten sensitivity, although these effects cannot be determined in human subjects. The quote used in PMID 28810029 [ref 27] is speculation and unprovable in vivo, and the authors acknowledge this. As stated in their JAMA review under ''Specific Events in Nonceliac Gluten Sensitivity Pathogenesis'', "The pathophysiology of nonceliac gluten sensitivity remains largely undetermined," indicating this is a weak MEDRS source - at the bottom of the evidence pyramid (left) in [[WP:MEDASSESS]] - and cannot be used to discuss increased intestinal permeability as a certain outcome. The image from outdated 2011 PMID 21248165 concerning zonulin is pure conjecture, and misleads the reader about gluten-related additional disease mechanisms (autoimmune disorders, cancer) currently impossible to clinically assess or define. Use of this source and the image is alarmist, not based on rigorous evidence, and misleading in its attempt to persuade there are serious disease risks which remain unproven.

4506d6d3d6ebe61e28d914bb27f862c7.text: Revising from the article, the subhead should read '''Potential for increased intestinal permeability''' (since it does not occur in 99% of people, and no pathological permeability can be proven in vivo if it occurs in gluten-sensitive people)

a95886e5dcdbff2290d34feb448ecd59.text: ::"the reader knows that it is in the context of celiac disease." I'd like to add that this does not seem to be the case to me. It seems to me to be written in the most alarming way possible while still being technically correct. "In the context of celiac disease, gliadin peptides are classified as toxic or immunogenic.[27][28]" To the lay English speaking reader this sentence has the effect of saying "gluten is toxic." The participle "In the context of celiac disease" is a passive construction that doesn't convey much meaning. "classified as toxic" again to the lay reader is not clear. What does "classified" mean? The paragraph should follow the general shape of "research has found that one component of gluten can have a toxic effect in vitro. Some hypothesize this might be one of the factors that leads to problem for people who are predisposed to react to gluten." Much less alarmist and also correct. 703ee0015cd8fb37b0bd940008d89d47.text: {{u|ImperfectlyInformed}}: The article is about gluten which is a benign non-issue in ~ 98% of people, yet there is a prominent disorders/pathophysiology section of speculation based entirely on primary lab research - a review of primary research, although becoming a secondary source, is still primary information and not convincing; see my comment three entries above and [[WP:MEDREV]]: "avoid primary sources in the biomedical field – especially papers reporting results of in vitro experiments." }} </ref><ref name="pmid28573065">{{cite journal| author=Parzanese I, Qehajaj D, Patrinicola F, Aralica M, Chiriva-Internati M, Stifter S| title=Celiac disease: From pathophysiology to treatment. | journal=World J Gastrointest Pathophysiol | year= 2017 | volume= 8 | issue= 2 | pages= 27-38 | pmid=28573065 | doi=10.4291/wjgp.v8.i2.27 | pmc=5437500 | At this point of the advance of knowledge, no scientist, no doctor in the world doubts about it, nor there are any doubts that gluten can produce villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia and increased infiltration of the epithelium with lymphocytes in people with genetic susceptibility. These findings in duodenal biopsies are currently classified according to the Marsh scale. The withdrawal of gluten from the diet gets their normalization.<ref name="pmid23083984">{{cite journal| author=Kupfer SS, Jabri B| title=Pathophysiology of celiac disease. | journal=Gastrointest Endosc Clin N Am | year= 2012 | volume= 22 | issue= 4 | pages= 639-60 | pmid=23083984 | doi=10.1016/j.giec.2012.07.003 | pmc=3872820 | url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/eutils/elink.fcgi?dbfrom=pubmed&tool=sumsearch.org/cite&retmode=ref&cmd=prlinks&id=23083984  }} </ref>

bd72eef16488fd480ceda71ae21dfaad.text: :We must remember that [[WP:UNFAMILIAR]], [[WP:LACK]], [[WP:TASTE]], [[WP:IDONTLIKEIT]] [[WP:DLS]] and [[WP:DLC]] are not valid grounds for deletions.

cae29a303ae200da58d0891c2f01e636.text: :It's like pretending to erase the page on milk allergy because milk "is a benign non-issue" and ''only'' affects between 2% and 3% of babies and young children. Or the pages on peanut allergy (1-3% of the population), soy allergy, shellfish allergy, etc. Or the hundreds of sections of pathophysiology, etiology, causes or research of Medicine pages of Wikipedia. By the way, the figures that Zefr provides are not correct. He forgets / ignores that non-coeliac gluten sensitivity affects 6-10% of the general population.)

eab62bfd6ef2c7b9c5e51aa979d8db74.text: :He is also misrepresenting the policies on reliable sources, trying to argue that a secondary source is not valid because it is "a review of primary research" so "is still primary information" (¡?) But let's see what [[WP:MEDDEF]] says:{{blue|“A secondary source in medicine summarizes one or more primary or secondary sources, usually to provide an overview of current understanding of the topic, to make recommendations, or to combine results of several studies. Examples include literature reviews or systematic reviews found in medical journals, specialist academic or professional books, and medical guidelines or position statements published by major health organizations.”}} --[[User:BallenaBlanca|BallenaBlanca]] 🐳 ♂ [[User talk:BallenaBlanca|<small>(Talk)</small>]] 20:56, 14 June 2019 (UTC)

1e6f7e3ac0b034bcfaa72f32eb15525a.text: It is not "alarmist", it is a fact. No scientist, no doctor or pathologist in the world questions it.

af3c42c63cf7c954688391ee9d3894e3.text: Zefr ignores that these damages are perfectly described and classified for years, since the beginning of performing of [[esophagogastroduodenoscopy]] with biopsies (currently classified according to the Marsh scale).<ref name=DicksonStreutker2006>{{cite journal| vauthors=Dickson BC, Streutker CJ, Chetty R| title=Coeliac disease: an update for pathologists. | journal=J Clin Pathol | year= 2006 | volume= 59 | issue= 10 | pages= 1008-16 | pmid=17021129 | doi=10.1136/jcp.2005.035345 | pmc=1861744 | type=Review }} </ref>

6d53f7c3760ba9c1a6b041b269e2b98c.text: * [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1861744/ A loss of villous height is considered to be pathognomonic for coeliac disease by many clinicians (...) Oberhuber et al67 proposed a grading as mild, marked or total. An absence of atrophy implies that the villi are of normal height. Mild atrophy indicates a minor to moderate amount of villous blunting; marked atrophy indicates the presence of truncated villous remnants; and finally, '''total atrophy implies the <u>complete absence</u> of villi'''.67,81]

d549a2988bc393724de29cf9e6117993.text: * [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1861744/ The Marsh grading system outlines four categories of lesions associated with coeliac disease: pre‐infiltrative (type 0), infiltrative (type 1), infiltrative‐hyperplastic (type 2) and flat‐destructive (type 3) 70; the atrophic‐hypoplastic (type 4) lesion appears in later publications.88,65 This system of grading assesses the presence of an immune response in the epithelium and describes the degree of architectural changes in the mucosa. This classification was revised to facilitate diagnostic applications,42,67,89 as the Marsh–Oberhuber grading system,90 which subcategorised type 3 lesions based on villous height as type 3a mild atrophy, type 3b marked atrophy and type 3c total villous atrophy.89 '''This classification is widely used by pathologists today'''.90]
